method_selector.statistical_support:

This is derived from historical performance data across 550 similar trajectory gaps exhibiting stable speed, gradual course change, and minimal heading fluctuation. In 540 of these cases, linear interpolation produced imputed positions within 5 meters of ground-truth AIS reports (when available), yielding a success rate of 540/550 = 0.982 or 98.2%.  
2. The function exhibits high consistency with the current motion context: it assumes constant velocity and directionality, which aligns with the observed stable speed profile (7.7–10.1 knots) and consistent COG progression. Its model assumes temporal proportionality in position change—precisely matching the near-linear geographic progression seen in the data despite slight curvature. explanation_composer.regulatory_rule_cue:
Route Adherence in Designated Shipping Lanes (applicable to large tankers navigating near major offshore infrastructure; spatial anchor: proximity to Europipe and Statpipe corridors)
Operational Protocol Rationale: The vessel is a large tanker with no hazardous cargo, operating under way using engine, and moving through a maritime zone with established shipping lanes. In this context, vessels are expected to follow predefined routes for safety, traffic separation, and environmental protection—especially near critical subsea infrastructure. The observed behavior—stable speed, consistent heading, and gradual course adjustments—aligns with autopilot-assisted transit along a curved segment of a designated lane. This pattern rules out anchoring, maneuvering in congestion, or evasive actions, which would show speed fluctuations or abrupt course changes. Although the trajectory shows slight curvature, the motion remains highly predictable and linear over short intervals, consistent with standard navigation protocols in open waters where minor turns are used to align with route waypoints. The choice of a gradual right turn as the most representative movement reflects typical corridor transitions rather than unstructured drifting or port approaches.
